title: GitHub Copilot Chat Not Capturing Terminal Output
body:
---

**Copilot Chat Extension Version:** `0.30.1`
**Copilot Extension Version:** `1.350.0`
**VS Code Version:** `1.103.1`
**OS Version:** `Arch Linux (Kernel 6.12.38-1-lts)`
**Feature:** `Run command from Copilot Chat`
**Selected model:** `GPT-4o, GPT-4.1, GPT-3.5, Claude 3.7 Sonnet` (issue occurs with all models)
**Logs:** *(see below)*

---

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Ask Copilot Chat to generate code.
2. Click **Run Command** in the Copilot output.
3. The command executes in the integrated terminal and completes successfully.
4. After execution finishes, Copilot Chat does **not** detect that the process has ended.
5. I have to manually pause/interrupt the process and paste the output back into Copilot Chat before it will continue.

---

### Expected Behavior

Copilot Chat should detect when the command has finished executing in the terminal and automatically capture the output into the chat conversation without requiring manual interruption or copy-paste.

---

### Actual Behavior

The process runs to completion in the terminal, but Copilot Chat keeps waiting indefinitely. Only after I manually pause or stop the copilot process and paste the output does Copilot Chat resume.

---

### Additional Information

Previously, Copilot Chat used to open a dedicated **Copilot terminal** when running commands. Now it uses my existing **zsh integrated terminal**, which may affect how process completion is detected. This behavior change might be related to the issue.

---

### Trace Log Snippet

```
2025-08-14 11:24:04.114 [debug] AgentIntent: rendering with budget=88518 (baseBudget: 111997, toolTokens: 7858), summarizationEnabled=true
2025-08-14 11:24:10.569 [trace] [NES][Triggerer][onDidChangeTextDocument] created
2025-08-14 11:24:10.569 [trace] [NES][Triggerer][onDidChangeTextDocument] Return: ignored document
2025-08-14 11:24:15.618 [trace] b0.initialize#6 started

```

title: Infinite loop when sending commands to VS Code integrated terminal
body:
Type: Bug When using **GitHub Copilot** (Chat / inline actions) to run a command in the **VS Code integrated terminal**, the extension gets stuck in an **infinite “sending to terminal” loop**. The command is never actually written to the terminal input, and the loop never stops unless I manually intervene (close the terminal / reload the window / disable the extension). This can keep running for a long time if left unattended (e.g., I left my computer and came back later and it was still looping). I’m concerned this may also cause **unnecessary backend/server resource usage**. --- ## Environment - **VS Code**: - **GitHub Copilot extension**: - **GitHub Copilot Chat extension**: - **OS**: Windows 10/11 - **Shell in Integrated Terminal**: PowerShell - **Node.js**: `node -v` - **Package manager**: pnpm > I can provide exact versions and logs if needed. --- ## Steps to Reproduce 1. Open a JS/TS project in VS Code. 2. Use **Copilot Chat** (inline chat / code lens / quick action) to run a command in the integrated terminal (e.g., “Run in Terminal” -> `pnpm dev`). 3. Observe that Copilot shows it is sending the command to the terminal. 4. The extension **does not actually send** the text to the terminal input and **keeps trying** in a loop. 5. The loop continues until I **manually** close the terminal, disable Copilot, or reload the window. **Expected behavior** - The command is sent **once** to the terminal and executed, or - If the terminal is busy/not ready, Copilot should **retry with backoff** or **show a clear error**, and - There should be a **timeout** that stops the process automatically if no progress is detected. **Actual behavior** - Copilot appears to be “sending” the command repeatedly, but nothing shows up in the terminal and it **never stops** on its own. **Frequency** - Intermittent but frequent (e.g., several times per day on my machine). --- ## Logs & Diagnostics I can attach logs, but here are the channels I checked: - **View → Output → “GitHub Copilot”** (and “GitHub Copilot Chat” if available) - **Help → Toggle Developer Tools → Console** - **F1 → “Developer: Set Log Level…” → Trace**, then reproduce the issue - **F1 → “Developer: Open Logs Folder”** and check `window.log` If it helps, during the loop I noticed repeated activity related to terminal interactions, but **no actual `sendText` completion** (looks like the terminal is never considered “ready”). --- ## Additional Context - Usually happens when the **integrated terminal was just created** by the extension or after the terminal loses focus briefly. - My shell is PowerShell; I have also seen it with CMD. It may be a race between terminal creation and `sendText` calls. --- ## Proposed Improvements 1. **Timeout / watchdog** for terminal command dispatch - Abort the operation after a configurable timeout (e.g., default 10–20 seconds) if there’s no observable progress (no write, no prompt, no cursor ready event). 2. **Progress detection & retry with backoff** - If the terminal isn’t ready (no prompt / busy), back off and **limit the number of retries** (e.g., 3–5 attempts). 3. **Resource-safety safeguards** - Prevent infinite loops that could cause unnecessary **CPU/network/server load**. - Add an **automatic cancel** when the user is idle or the terminal window is detached/closed. 4. **Clear UI feedback** - Show a **non-blocking notification** with “Retry / Cancel / Copy command” options when the timeout triggers. 5. **Telemetry / correlation** - Emit a **correlation ID** for the terminal dispatch attempt and record “terminal ready” vs “sendText resolved” events to help diagnose races. --- ## Workarounds I’m using - Manually **close/reopen the integrated terminal**. - **Reload Window** (`Developer: Reload Window`). - Temporarily **disable/enable** Copilot extensions. --- ## Minimal Example Command This happens with many commands; an easy repro is: ``` pnpm dev ``` (Triggered via Copilot Chat “Run in Terminal” on a JavaScript project.) --- Thanks for looking into this! Let me know if I can provide a screen recording or detailed logs. **Reporter:** @GuillermoCopello (Windows, JS project with pnpm) Extension version: 0.30.1 VS Code version: Code 1.103.0 (e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f, 2025-08-06T21:40:10.271Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.22631 Modes:

Copilot Chat loses entered text if up arrow pressed
body:
Type: Bug In a GHCP chat: 1. Enter and submit a message 2. When ready, start typing the next message 3. Press the up arrow key on the keyboard (only once if the text you entered is on one line, otherwise you may have to press multiple times) 4. This is very frustrating. I just lost a long answer to the question GHCP asked me. I would expect that the up-arrow-populates-last-message only works if I have an empty chat message. title: Enable strict by default in implicit js/ts projects
body:
This PR adds a new setting `js/ts.implicitProjectConfig.strict` that enables strict mode by default for JavaScript and TypeScript files that are not part of a project (no tsconfig.json or jsconfig.json).

## Changes

- **New setting**: `js/ts.implicitProjectConfig.strict` (defaults to `true`)
- **Configuration integration**: Added `strict` property to `ImplicitProjectConfiguration` class
- **Compiler options**: Updated `inferredProjectCompilerOptions()` to include strict mode when enabled
- **TSConfig generation**: Generated tsconfig.json files now include `"strict": true` when the setting is enabled
- **Localization**: Added proper description for the new setting

## Behavior

### When `js/ts.implicitProjectConfig.strict: true` (default)
- Implicit JS/TS projects get strict type checking enabled
- Generated tsconfig.json includes `"strict": true`
- Aligns with TypeScript 6.0's direction toward strict by default

### When `js/ts.implicitProjectConfig.strict: false`
- Maintains previous behavior with looser type checking
- Generated tsconfig.json omits the strict setting

### Existing projects
Files that are already part of a project (have tsconfig.json/jsconfig.json) are **not affected** by this setting - their existing configuration takes precedence.

## Implementation

The implementation follows the established pattern of existing implicit project settings like `strictNullChecks` and `strictFunctionTypes`. The setting is automatically detected by VS Code's configuration change system and properly propagated to the TypeScript service.

```typescript
// Example generated tsconfig.json with strict enabled
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "strict": true,
    "module": "ESNext", 
    "target": "ES2022"
    // ... other options
  }
}
```

Fixes #260168.

title: Copilot Inline Chat in VS Code Jupyter Notebooks Produces Immutable Preview Cells Instead of Applying Direct Model Edits to Active NotebookCellDocument

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
Type: Bug Following recent updates to the github.copilot and/or github.copilot-chat extensions, invoking Inline Chat (editor.action.inlineChat.start, default Ctrl+I) within a notebookEditor context (Jupyter .ipynb) no longer mutates the active NotebookCellDocument’s text buffer in-place. Instead, the Copilot edit operation spawns a new read-only virtual editor instance (likely a CustomTextEditor or synthetic NotebookCell in preview mode) to display proposed changes. This virtualized cell instance is opened with a isReadonly flag set to true and is not associated with the backing Uri of the original cell. Attempting any mutation on this preview cell triggers the standard VS Code message: Cannot edit in read-only editor The original NotebookCell remains unchanged in the underlying NotebookDocument, but in the UI it is visually replaced or pushed below the preview cell. This results in an apparent loss of editability unless the user manually copies the preview’s content into a live cell. the bag: when using Inline Chat in Jupyter notebooks (Ctrl+I). Steps to reproduce on my setup: Open a .ipynb in VS Code (stable release). Place cursor inside a code cell. Press Ctrl+I to trigger Copilot Inline Chat. Enter a prompt (e.g., “refactor this loop into a comprehension”) and run it. Observed behaviour: Instead of editing the active cell in place, Copilot replaces it with a read-only preview cell. Trying to type in this cell shows “Cannot edit in read-only editor.” Expected behaviour: The AI-generated change should apply directly to the active NotebookCellDocument so I can immediately continue editing, as it did in earlier versions. This behaviour started recently older Copilot versions did not create these immutable preview cells for Inline Chat in notebooks. It happens consistently in .ipynb, but not in .py files. I also confirmed that on another PC running an older, (not updated) version of VS Code, but fully synced with my settings, the Inline Chat feature behaved as expected in Jupyter notebooks applying edits directly to the active NotebookCellDocument without creating a read-only cell. title: Copilot Agent Mode : Product Feedback (Features, Bugs, UX Gaps)
body:
This issue summarizes direct product feedback for VS Code Copilot Agent Mode, focusing on default user experience and feature gaps. Please see below for specific actionable items, categorized by severity:

CRITICAL
- [ ] Raise "maximum requests" for all users to 50. 
- [ ] Allow users to "Allow List" commands for auto-approval during a session, with the ability to toggle auto-accept on/off. Current settings require manual approval and only take effect after restarting the chat, which is suboptimal.

IMPORTANT
- [ ] Implement "auto" model selection/mixing (e.g., Opus, Sonnet, Haiku) for best results.
- [ ] Bug/UX: VS Code creates excessive new terminal sessions, especially for dev servers. Prefer reusing integrated terminals and ensure agent reads output from the correct session.

NICE TO HAVE
- [ ] Default to automatic planning (break tasks into steps, track progress) to increase trust and coach better developer workflows.
- [ ] More dynamic activity indicator (e.g., animated thinking, token usage) to convey agent progress and avoid static "Working..." UI.
- [ ] Visual indicator for context window usage, so users know when they're close to summary/compaction limits.
- [ ] More intuitive agent change flow ("accept"/"auto-accept" vs "Keep"/"Undo"). Current paradigm risks accidental code loss.
- [ ] Improve chat semantics ("Yes"/"No"/"No, do it differently") for agent iteration, rather than "Continue"/"Cancel".

title: Add activation guards to prevent multiple Python activation in shell integration scripts
body:
This PR adds activation guards to prevent infinite Python activation loops in VS Code's shell integration scripts, addressing an issue where Python environments could be activated multiple times recursively.

The solution implements `VSCODE_PYTHON_AUTOACTIVATE_GUARD` environment variable checks before Python activation hooks in all four shell integration scripts:

- **Bash** (`shellIntegration-bash.sh`): Uses `[ -z "$VSCODE_PYTHON_AUTOACTIVATE_GUARD" ]` guard
- **Zsh** (`shellIntegration-rc.zsh`): Uses `[ -z "$VSCODE_PYTHON_AUTOACTIVATE_GUARD" ]` guard  
- **Fish** (`shellIntegration.fish`): Uses `if not set -q VSCODE_PYTHON_AUTOACTIVATE_GUARD` guard
- **PowerShell** (`shellIntegration.ps1`): Uses `if (-not $env:VSCODE_PYTHON_AUTOACTIVATE_GUARD)` guard

## Implementation Details

The guard mechanism follows this pattern for each shell:
1. Check if `VSCODE_PYTHON_AUTOACTIVATE_GUARD` is unset/empty (or undefined for Fish using `set -q`)
2. If unset, set the guard variable to "1" 
3. Execute the Python activation script
4. Clear the guard variable after completion

This prevents re-entrant activation calls while preserving all existing error handling, logging, and functionality. The guard is always cleaned up properly, even if activation fails.

The Fish shell implementation uses the idiomatic `set -q` syntax to check for variable existence rather than empty values, following the pattern used in vscode-python-environments.

## Example

Before this change, if a Python activation script tried to source VS Code's shell integration again, it would create an infinite loop. Now:

```bash
# First activation - guard allows it
if [ -z "$VSCODE_PYTHON_AUTOACTIVATE_GUARD" ]; then
    export VSCODE_PYTHON_AUTOACTIVATE_GUARD=1
    # Python activation happens here
    builtin unset VSCODE_PYTHON_AUTOACTIVATE_GUARD
fi

# Subsequent attempts - guard blocks them
# (guard is set, so activation is skipped)
```

Fixes #261529.

title: Built-in multi-step custom modes for breaking down complex agent workflows
body:
Key scenarios:

- Plan: Plan implementation steps → Implement step by step → ✅
- Spec-Driven: Product Spec ↺ Design Plan ↺ Implementation Plan ↺ Implement → ✅
- Deep Architect: Draft Architecture ↺ Review Draft ↺ Implement → ✅
- TDD: Plan ↺ Red Phase _(Failing Tests)_ → Green Phase _(Make Tests Pass)_ → Refactor Phase _(Improve Code)_ → ✅
- Low-code mockup flow for UX ideation: Brainstorm Solutions → Prototype Solutions → Iterate → Converge → ✅


Approach:
- v0: Baseline built-in plan/implement mode that can be easily customized to more specific engineering workflows
- Assume workflows can combine modes and prompts
- Combine with onboarding #260212 to make sure users benefit from built-in flows and any team customizations.

title: MCP install custom URI scheme (vscode:/mcp?install) breaks various workflows

labels.name: *as-designed
labels.description: Described behavior is as designed

body:
The VS Code links to install an MCP server, such as `vscode:mcp/install?%7B%22name%22%3A%22github%22%2C%22gallery%22%3Atrue%2C%22url%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fapi.githubcopilot.com%2Fmcp%2F%22%7D` (via: <https://code.visualstudio.com/mcp>) uses a custom URI scheme that breaks various workflows. 

This means we cannot link to it from a .md file inside GitHub (e.g. https://github.com/microsoft/wassette/blob/main/docs/mcp-clients.md ).

It also means we cannot redirect to it using various URL shorteners (such as our internal ones).

Others would include a full URL such as `https://example.com/install-mcp?name=wassette&config=...`

UPDATE: I've since discovered the `https://vscode.dev/redirect?url=` redirect option (e.g. https://vscode.dev/redirect?url=vscode:mcp/install?%7B%22name%22%3A%22wassette%22%2C%22gallery%22%3Afalse%2C%22command%22%3A%22wassette%22%2C%22args%22%3A%5B%22serve%22%2C%22--stdio%22%5D%7D which we now use in our our our .md doc above), but I don't remember finding this documented anywhere (we may have discovered it indirectly via the GitHub MCP server repo).

title: Replace request-light with native fetch in npm extension
body:
This PR migrates the built-in npm extension from using `request-light` to the native `fetch` API, eliminating an external dependency while maintaining full functionality.

## Changes Made

- **Created `fetch.ts`**: A new module that provides an XHRRequest-compatible interface using native `fetch`, ensuring seamless replacement without breaking existing code
- **Updated all imports**: Modified `npmMain.ts`, `npmBrowserMain.ts`, `jsonContributions.ts`, and `packageJSONContribution.ts` to use the new fetch implementation
- **Removed dependency**: Eliminated `request-light` from package.json
- **Enhanced header handling**: Added special mapping for the `agent` header to `User-Agent` to maintain compatibility with npm registry API expectations
- **Simplified proxy handling**: Removed custom proxy configuration code since native fetch handles proxy settings at the system level

## Key Benefits

- **Reduced bundle size**: Eliminates the request-light dependency
- **Modern API**: Uses the standard fetch API available in all supported environments
- **Maintained compatibility**: All existing HTTP requests work identically, including npm registry searches and package info retrieval
- **Better maintainability**: Less external dependencies to manage

## Testing

Verified that all npm extension functionality works correctly:
- Package search in package.json dependencies sections
- Package completion suggestions 
- Package hover information
- Scoped package (@types) searches
- Both browser and desktop extension contexts

The implementation has been tested against live npm registry APIs to ensure compatibility.

Fixes #261527.

title: Nuget tests should not depend on dotnet being installed on the machine
body: These tests fail https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat/blob/main/src/extension/mcp/test/vscode-node/nuget.spec.ts if the developer does not have the latest version of .net installed on their machine. This is not a requirement for developing copilot chat and we should not require it of developers. The tests should use mock data to avoid hitting the real CLI.

title: "Coordinate" typo in src\vs\editor\browser\services\hoverService\hoverWidget.ts
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes.

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.104.0 (OSS Dev)
- OS Version: Windows 11 (Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In source, go to `src\vs\editor\browser\services\hoverService\hoverWidget.ts` 
2. On line 397, 398, and 412, `computeXCordinate` and `computeYCordinate` functions should be `computeXCoordinate` and `computeYCoordinate` respectively.

Note that this is an issue that is not within the UI, but rather in the source code itself.

labels.description: Task system issues

labels.name: insiders-released
labels.description: Patch has been released in VS Code Insiders

body:
Currently, the agent mentions errors in compilation even if it eventually succeeds. 

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ced7ae38-452c-4bd1-8bd4-84f848cc60b9

Idea from @Tyriar: use problem matcher result instead of full output and LLM eval for tasks with problem matchers. 

This will improve accuracy and speed.

title: Make sure \b works in regex check

labels.name: *as-designed
labels.description: Described behavior is as designed

labels.name: chat-terminal
labels.description: The run in terminal tool in chat

body:
I expected this terminal auto approve rule:

```
"for ($i = 1; $i -le 100; $i++) { Get-Date -Format \"yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss\"; Start-Sleep 1 }": { "approve": true, "matchCommandLine": true }
```

To work for `for ($i = 1; $i -le 100; $i++) { Get-Date -Format "yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss"; Start-Sleep 1 }`, but it doesn't due to the `\b` that gets added to the end. Need to make sure that is working as expected

title: Fix inconsistent setting value formatting in configuration descriptions
body:
Fixes inconsistent formatting of setting value references in configuration descriptions across VS Code core files.

## Problem

Setting value references in `markdownDescription` fields were inconsistently formatted:

1. **workbench.contribution.ts line 88**: Used `'{1}'` (with quotes around placeholder) instead of `{1}` 
2. **files.contribution.ts line 278**: Used constant `AutoSaveConfiguration.AFTER_DELAY` instead of backtick-wrapped string

This inconsistency meant some setting values weren't properly formatted for markdown rendering in the Settings UI.

## Solution

### workbench.contribution.ts
```typescript
// Before
'markdownDescription': localize(..., "...when {0} is not set to '{1}'.", '`#workbench.editor.showTabs#`', '`multiple`')

// After  
'markdownDescription': localize(..., "...when {0} is not set to {1}.", '`#workbench.editor.showTabs#`', '`multiple`')
```

### files.contribution.ts
```typescript
// Before
'markdownDescription': nls.localize(..., "...when `#files.autoSave#` is set to `{0}`.", AutoSaveConfiguration.AFTER_DELAY)

// After
'markdownDescription': nls.localize(..., "...when `#files.autoSave#` is set to `{0}`.", '`afterDelay`')
```

## Impact

- Ensures consistent formatting of setting value references across the codebase
- Improves proper rendering of setting values in the Settings UI
- Aligns with the established pattern used in 20+ other setting descriptions

title: Feature Request: Persist Code Folding State Per File Across Sessions

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

labels.name: editor-folding
labels.description: Editor code folding issues

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

**Problem**
When working on large files in VS Code, I often fold specific sections (e.g., imports, utility functions, long comments) to keep the view clean.
However, if I close VS Code or reopen the project, all folded sections are reset.
This forces me to manually re-fold code every time, which disrupts my workflow and slows me down.

**Proposed Solution**
Could you add a setting to persist folding states for each file in the current workspace?

- Store folding ranges in the workspace’s storage (not in the source file, to avoid git changes).
- Restore the same folded/unfolded state when reopening the file, switching between files, or restarting VS Code.
- Provide a setting in settings.json, e.g.:

`"workbench.editor.restoreFolds": true`

**Benefits**

- Efficiency: Eliminates repetitive manual folding for frequently edited large files.
- Readability: Maintains the code view's consistency with the developer’s preferred structure.
- Consistency: Aligns with existing behaviour for persisting cursor position and view state.

title: Chat in Editor should have same background as chat in panel
body:
Expected: When I move/open a chat to the editor, it should appear the same and use the same colors.
Actual: It's using a lighter (in dark mode) color from the editor. 

Since we haven't designed the chat elements for this background color, it's having some unintended consequences. Examples:
- https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/234866
- Todo styling looks incomplete/broken
- Color contrast ratios for foreground/background (ex. checkpoints UI) **does not meet accessibility standards**
